intro: Trillium kamtschaticum subsp. rhombifolium, commonly known as the rhombifoliate wake-robin, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Melanthiaceae and is characterized by its three broadly elliptic leaves and a single erect stem bearing a single white or pale pink flower. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded forest environments, often in areas with rich, well-drained soil. It produces a cluster of small, reddish-brown berries that contain the seeds. This subspecies is noted for its distinctive rhomboid-shaped leaves and its role in early spring floral displays.
